If double precision isn't required thats great - my concern is based 
on a number of comments in the book Neural Network and Fuzzy Logic 
Applications by Stephen Welstead concerning precision - most of his 
examples use double precision weight arrays.  In particular he points 
out that double precision is required in applications involving 
chaotic processes.  Pentiums have dedicated double precision floating 
point hardware that is extremely efficient while the majority of 
embedded processors implement single precision floating point in 
software and usually don't support double precision at all.

> Are you able to elaborate on the types of problem you're 
considering?
> 
We are investigating the development of a real time, using ANN based, 
in-scene object recognizer/tracker running on an embedded processor 
(Analog Devices Blackfin) possibly augmented with a floating point co-
processor (Analog Devices Shark) .  We're just getting starting and 
the threads here have been very helpful.  The show stopper is double 
verse single precision.  

Steve
